findings.title: arbitrary-send-eth
findings.description:
VulnerableEnterpriseContract.lottery() (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#924-936) sends eth to arbitrary user
	Dangerous calls:
	- address(msg.sender).transfer(address(this).balance) (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#934)

findings.title: arbitrary-send-eth
findings.description:
VulnerableEnterpriseContract.emergencyWithdraw() (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#770-773) sends eth to arbitrary user
	Dangerous calls:
	- address(msg.sender).transfer(address(this).balance) (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#772)

findings.title: arbitrary-send-eth
findings.description:
VulnerableEnterpriseContract.frontRunVulnerable(uint256) (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#1041-1047) sends eth to arbitrary user
	Dangerous calls:
	- address(msg.sender).transfer(address(this).balance) (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#1045)

findings.title: arbitrary-send-eth
findings.description:
VulnerableEnterpriseContract.flashLoan(uint256) (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#875-887) sends eth to arbitrary user
	Dangerous calls:
	- address(msg.sender).transfer(amount) (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#879)

findings.title: arbitrary-send-eth
findings.description:
VulnerableEnterpriseContract.batchTransfer(address[],uint256[]) (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#862-867) sends eth to arbitrary user
	Dangerous calls:
	- recipients[i].call{value: amounts[i]}() (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#865)

findings.title: arbitrary-send-eth
findings.description:
VulnerableEnterpriseContract.distributeToAll() (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#939-945) sends eth to arbitrary user
	Dangerous calls:
	- address(users[i]).transfer(1000000000000000000) (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#943)

findings.title: weak-prng
findings.description: VulnerableEnterpriseContract.lottery() (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#924-936) uses a weak PRNG: "winningNumber = uint256(keccak256(bytes)(abi.encodePacked(blockhash(uint256)(block.number - 1),msg.sender))) % 10 (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#928-931)"

findings.title: weak-prng
findings.description: VulnerableEnterpriseContract.weakRandom() (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#965-967) uses a weak PRNG: "uint256(keccak256(bytes)(abi.encodePacked(block.timestamp))) % 100 (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#966)"

findings.title: weak-prng
findings.description: VulnerableEnterpriseContract.getTokenPrice() (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#781-784) uses a weak PRNG: "(block.timestamp % 1000) + 100 (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#783)"

findings.title: weak-prng
findings.description: VulnerableEnterpriseContract.generateRandomNumber() (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#911-922) uses a weak PRNG: "randomNum = uint256(keccak256(bytes)(abi.encodePacked(block.timestamp,block.difficulty,block.coinbase,nonce ++))) % 1000 (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#913-918)"

findings.title: controlled-delegatecall
findings.description:
VulnerableEnterpriseContract.delegateToContract(address,bytes) (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#869-872) uses delegatecall to a input-controlled function id
	- target.delegatecall(data) (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#871)

findings.title: controlled-delegatecall
findings.description:
VulnerableEnterpriseContract.fallback() (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#1007-1014) uses delegatecall to a input-controlled function id
	- target.delegatecall(msg.data) (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#1011)

findings.title: reentrancy-eth
findings.description:
Reentrancy in VulnerableEnterpriseContract.withdrawBalance() (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#833-843):
	External calls:
	- (success,None) = msg.sender.call{value: amount}() (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#837)
	State variables written after the call(s):
	- userBalances[msg.sender] = 0 (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#841)
	VulnerableEnterpriseContract.userBalances (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#734) can be used in cross function reentrancies:
	- VulnerableEnterpriseContract.complexWithdraw(address) (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#845-854)
	- VulnerableEnterpriseContract.distributeRewards() (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#797-808)
	- VulnerableEnterpriseContract.setUserBalance(address,uint256) (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#822-825)
	- VulnerableEnterpriseContract.userBalances (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#734)
	- VulnerableEnterpriseContract.withdrawBalance() (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#833-843)

findings.title: reentrancy-eth
findings.description:
Reentrancy in VulnerableEnterpriseContract.complexWithdraw(address) (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#845-854):
	External calls:
	- (success,None) = recipient.call{value: amount / 2}() (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#850)
	External calls sending eth:
	- address(recipient).transfer(amount / 2) (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#849)
	- (success,None) = recipient.call{value: amount / 2}() (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#850)
	State variables written after the call(s):
	- userBalances[msg.sender] = 0 (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#853)
	VulnerableEnterpriseContract.userBalances (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#734) can be used in cross function reentrancies:
	- VulnerableEnterpriseContract.complexWithdraw(address) (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#845-854)
	- VulnerableEnterpriseContract.distributeRewards() (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#797-808)
	- VulnerableEnterpriseContract.setUserBalance(address,uint256) (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#822-825)
	- VulnerableEnterpriseContract.userBalances (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#734)
	- VulnerableEnterpriseContract.withdrawBalance() (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#833-843)

findings.title: suicidal
findings.description: VulnerableEnterpriseContract.destroy() (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#970-973) allows anyone to destruct the contract

findings.title: incorrect-equality
findings.description:
VulnerableEnterpriseContract.lottery() (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#924-936) uses a dangerous strict equality:
	- winningNumber == 7 (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#933)

findings.title: unchecked-lowlevel
findings.description: VulnerableEnterpriseContract.batchTransfer(address[],uint256[]) (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#862-867) ignores return value by recipients[i].call{value: amounts[i]}() (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#865)

findings.title: unchecked-lowlevel
findings.description: VulnerableEnterpriseContract.fallback() (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#1007-1014) ignores return value by target.delegatecall(msg.data) (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#1011)

findings.title: unchecked-lowlevel
findings.description: VulnerableEnterpriseContract.makeExternalCall(address,bytes) (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#857-860) ignores return value by target.call(data) (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#859)

findings.title: unchecked-lowlevel
findings.description: VulnerableEnterpriseContract.delegateToContract(address,bytes) (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#869-872) ignores return value by target.delegatecall(data) (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#871)

findings.title: missing-zero-check
findings.description:
VulnerableEnterpriseContract.complexWithdraw(address).recipient (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#845) lacks a zero-check on :
		- address(recipient).transfer(amount / 2) (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#849)

	- Version constraint >=0.4.16 is used by:
		->=0.4.16 (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#309)
	- Version constraint >=0.6.2 is used by:
		->=0.6.2 (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#392)
	- Version constraint ^0.8.19 is used by:
		-^0.8.19 (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#725)

findings.title: solc-version
findings.description:
Version constraint ^0.8.19 contains known severe issues (https://solidity.readthedocs.io/en/latest/bugs.html)
	- VerbatimInvalidDeduplication
	- FullInlinerNonExpressionSplitArgumentEvaluationOrder
	- MissingSideEffectsOnSelectorAccess.
It is used by:
	- ^0.8.19 (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#725)

	- KeccakCaching
	- EmptyByteArrayCopy
	- DynamicArrayCleanup
	- ImplicitConstructorCallvalueCheck
	- TupleAssignmentMultiStackSlotComponents
	- MemoryArrayCreationOverflow
	- privateCanBeOverridden
	- SignedArrayStorageCopy
	- ABIEncoderV2StorageArrayWithMultiSlotElement
	- DynamicConstructorArgumentsClippedABIV2
	- UninitializedFunctionPointerInConstructor_0.4.x
	- IncorrectEventSignatureInLibraries_0.4.x
	- ExpExponentCleanup
	- NestedArrayFunctionCallDecoder
	- ZeroFunctionSelector.
It is used by:
	- >=0.4.16 (flattened/vulnerableppxty.sol#309)

findings.title: Integer Arithmetic Bugs
findings.description:
The arithmetic operator can underflow.
It is possible to cause an integer overflow or underflow in the arithmetic operation.
findings.recommendation: Review SWC-101 vulnerability: Integer Arithmetic Bugs

findings.title: Integer Arithmetic Bugs
findings.description:
The arithmetic operator can overflow.
It is possible to cause an integer overflow or underflow in the arithmetic operation.
findings.recommendation: Review SWC-101 vulnerability: Integer Arithmetic Bugs

findings.title: Integer Arithmetic Bugs
findings.description:
The arithmetic operator can overflow.
It is possible to cause an integer overflow or underflow in the arithmetic operation.
findings.recommendation: Review SWC-101 vulnerability: Integer Arithmetic Bugs

findings.title: Unprotected Ether Withdrawal
findings.description:
Any sender can withdraw Ether from the contract account.
Arbitrary senders other than the contract creator can profitably extract Ether from the contract account. Verify the business logic carefully and make sure that appropriate security controls are in place to prevent unexpected loss of funds.
findings.recommendation: Review SWC-105 vulnerability: Unprotected Ether Withdrawal

findings.title: External Call To User-Supplied Address
findings.description:
A call to a user-supplied address is executed.
An external message call to an address specified by the caller is executed. Note that the callee account might contain arbitrary code and could re-enter any function within this contract. Reentering the contract in an intermediate state may lead to unexpected behaviour. Make sure that no state modifications are executed after this call and/or reentrancy guards are in place.
findings.recommendation: Review SWC-107 vulnerability: External Call To User-Supplied Address

findings.title: Transaction Order Dependence
findings.description:
The value of the call is dependent on balance or storage write
This can lead to race conditions. An attacker may be able to run a transaction after our transaction which can change the value of the call
findings.recommendation: Review SWC-114 vulnerability: Transaction Order Dependence

findings.title: State access after external call
findings.description:
Write to persistent state following external call
The contract account state is accessed after an external call to a user defined address. To prevent reentrancy issues, consider accessing the state only before the call, especially if the callee is untrusted. Alternatively, a reentrancy lock can be used to prevent untrusted callees from re-entering the contract in an intermediate state.
findings.recommendation: Review SWC-107 vulnerability: State access after external call

findings.title: Unprotected Selfdestruct
findings.description:
Any sender can cause the contract to self-destruct.
Any sender can trigger execution of the SELFDESTRUCT instruction to destroy this contract account and withdraw its balance to an arbitrary address. Review the transaction trace generated for this issue and make sure that appropriate security controls are in place to prevent unrestricted access.
findings.recommendation: Review SWC-106 vulnerability: Unprotected Selfdestruct

findings.title: Integer Arithmetic Bugs
findings.description:
The arithmetic operator can underflow.
It is possible to cause an integer overflow or underflow in the arithmetic operation.
findings.recommendation: Review SWC-101 vulnerability: Integer Arithmetic Bugs

findings.title: Unprotected Ether Withdrawal
findings.description:
Any sender can withdraw Ether from the contract account.
Arbitrary senders other than the contract creator can profitably extract Ether from the contract account. Verify the business logic carefully and make sure that appropriate security controls are in place to prevent unexpected loss of funds.
findings.recommendation: Review SWC-105 vulnerability: Unprotected Ether Withdrawal

findings.title: Dependence on predictable environment variable
findings.description:
A control flow decision is made based on The block.timestamp environment variable.
The block.timestamp environment variable is used to determine a control flow decision. Note that the values of variables like coinbase, gaslimit, block number and timestamp are predictable and can be manipulated by a malicious miner. Also keep in mind that attackers know hashes of earlier blocks. Don't use any of those environment variables as sources of randomness and be aware that use of these variables introduces a certain level of trust into miners.
findings.recommendation: Review SWC-116 vulnerability: Dependence on predictable environment variable

findings.title: Dependence on predictable environment variable

Also keep in mind that attackers know hashes of earlier blocks. Don't use any of those environment variables as sources of randomness and be aware that use of these variables introduces a certain level of trust into miners.

findings.title: Dependence on predictable environment variable
findings.description:
A control flow decision is made based on The block.number environment variable.
The block.number environment variable is used to determine a control flow decision. Note that the values of variables like coinbase, gaslimit, block number and timestamp are predictable and can be manipulated by a malicious miner. Also keep in mind that attackers know hashes of earlier blocks. Don't use any of those environment variables as sources of randomness and be aware that use of these variables introduces a certain level of trust into miners.
findings.recommendation: Review SWC-120 vulnerability: Dependence on predictable environment variable

findings.title: Exception State
findings.description:
An assertion violation was triggered.
It is possible to trigger an assertion violation. Note that Solidity assert() statements should only be used to check invariants. Review the transaction trace generated for this issue and either make sure your program logic is correct, or use require() instead of assert() if your goal is to constrain user inputs or enforce preconditions. Remember to validate inputs from both callers (for instance, via passed arguments) and callees (for instance, via return values).
findings.recommendation: Review SWC-110 vulnerability: Exception State

findings.title: Storage Operation in Loop
findings.description: Storage operations in loops consume high gas. Consider using memory or optimizing loop structure.
findings.recommendation: Cache storage reads in memory variables or restructure the loop.

findings.title: Multiple Storage Reads
findings.description: Multiple storage reads detected. Consider caching in memory variable.
findings.recommendation: Store frequently accessed storage values in memory variables.

findings.recommendation: Add SafeMath library or require() checks before subtraction.
